Message.Title: "The Alibaba Phenomenon"
Message.Msg: This week The Economist, arguably the world's most respected business magazine, dedicated its cover (ex U.K. and Europe) to the rise of Alibaba Group, which sits atop China's booming e-commerce market. In a front-of-the-book editorial and a three-page feature, the magazine's writers pose the question: Could a Chinese Internet business become the world's most valuable company? The authors note that Alibaba, riding China's giant online shopping wave, is on track to become the first e-commerce firm to handle $1 trillion in annual transactions. Meanwhile, an anticipated IPO by the company is "sure to be the most trumpeted since Facebook's listing last year - and possible even bigger, too."

Topic.Title: "The Alibaba Phenomenon"

Message.Msg: Wow! bigger than Facebook!!

Message.Title: Small Float Mobile Play Ready to Make HUGE Gains this Week!
Message.Msg: Concurrent (CCUR) gained the past 5 days straight and is ready to explode! Virgin Media (VMED) a $23 billion company (largest cable TV company in UK) just announced they are deploying CCUR's MediaHawk technology to power their Virgin TV Anywhere platform so that their 3.8mm subscribers can watch on demand videos from any location on their tablets and smartphones. CCUR's EPS last quarter was double the quarter before and quadruple two quarters ago. CCUR sitting on $24.6mm in cash and has no debt, enterprise value of only $47mm or just 0.75x their revenue of $62.59mm. CCUR's main rival Seachange (SEAC) has lower margins and is losing money yet it's being valued with enterprise value of 1.85x revenue, which would value CCUR over $15 per share. CCUR could double to $15 very rapidly over the next week!

Message.Title: Yahoo Buying Summly to Boost Searches on Mobile Devices - Bloomberg
Message.Msg: Yahoo! Inc. said it’s buying mobile-product company Summly to simplify how consumers access information. Summly, created by Nick D’Aloisio at the age of 15 in London, allows users of mobile devices such as smartphones and tablets to more easily find the news and information that’s important to them, Yahoo said in a blog posting today.

Topic.Title: Why So Much Spam on Yahoo Message Boards?

Message.Msg: Yahoo has bigger problems than the functionality, look/feel of their finance message boards. By deleting urls which link to contrarian analysis, particularly of pink sheet fraud promoters WHILE allowing both the spam bots and the actual paid advertising from the stock shill firms Yahoo potentially opens itself to being joined as a secondary (just for cash recovery!!) defendant for any tout firm hit with a civil suit. Step 1: Yahoo advertiser penalized in SEC action. Step 2: Yahoo records reveal suppression of message board postings against that advertiser (Yahoo facilitates their activities as it were) at this point whether it's automated or discretionary is irrelevant. Step 3: Plaintiffs, recognizing that the touts are long gone and damages unrecoverable, attempts to join Yahoo in the "I"ve been swindled" case. Step 4: ?? Winning isn't everything, sometimes just shining a bright light can be cringe worthy. Bottom Line: Enabling the stock fraud promoters while silencing the MB critics is a risk I wouldn't want my management to take...what think you??

Message.Title: Solid support at 23.30. . . holding since $15
Message.Msg: Tested hard 3 intervals today and held 23.30 like a rock. Nice thing about yahoo that while the run has been significant, it has not been an abnormal parabolic spike (i.e. 20%+ in a day, 50% in a week, etc) but has been a stable, slow and steady rise, resulting in significant support levels along the way. Still has some more gap to fill back to the mid 2000s levels.
